metadata.title: Deep-Learning Channel Estimation for IRS-Assisted Integrated Sensing and Communication System
metadata.abstract: Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC), and intelligent reflecting surface (IRS) are envisioned as revolutionary technologies to enhance spectral and energy efficiencies for next wireless system generations. For the first time, this paper focuses on the channel estimation problem in an IRS-assisted ISAC system. This problem is challenging due to the lack of signal processing capacity in passive IRS, as well as the presence of mutual interference between sensing and communication (SAC) signals in ISAC systems. A three-stage approach is proposed to decouple the estimation problem into sub-ones, including the estimation of the direct SAC channels in the first stage, reflected communication channel in the second stage, and reflected sensing channel in the third stage. The proposed three-stage approach is based on a deep-learning framework, which involves two different convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures to estimate the channels at the full-duplex ISAC base station. Furthermore, two types of input-output pairs to train the CNNs are carefully designed, which affect the estimation performance under various signal-to-noise ratio conditions and system parameters. Simulation results validate the superiority of the proposed estimation approach compared to the least-squares baseline scheme, and its computational complexity is also analyzed.

grobid.contents:
Deep-Learning Channel Estimation for IRS-Assisted Integrated Sensing and Communication System
MAY 2023

Yu Liu 
Senior Member, IEEEIbrahim Al-Nahhal 
Fellow, IEEEOctavia A Dobre 
Senior Member, IEEEFanggang Wang 
Deep-Learning Channel Estimation for IRS-Assisted Integrated Sensing and Communication System

IEEE TRANSACTIONS ON VEHICULAR TECHNOLOGY
725MAY 202310.1109/TVT.2022.32317276181
Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC), and intelligent reflecting surface (IRS) are envisioned as revolutionary technologies to enhance spectral and energy efficiencies for next wireless system generations. For the first time, this paper focuses on the channel estimation problem in an IRS-assisted ISAC system. This problem is challenging due to the lack of signal processing capacity in passive IRS, as well as the presence of mutual interference between sensing and communication (SAC) signals in ISAC systems. A three-stage approach is proposed to decouple the estimation problem into sub-ones, including the estimation of the direct SAC channels in the first stage, reflected communication channel in the second stage, and reflected sensing channel in the third stage. The proposed three-stage approach is based on a deep-learning framework, which involves two different convolutional neural network (CNN) architectures to estimate the channels at the full-duplex ISAC base station. Furthermore, two types of input-output pairs to train the CNNs are carefully designed, which affect the estimation performance under various signal-to-noise ratio conditions and system parameters. Simulation results validate the superiority of the proposed estimation approach compared to the least-squares baseline scheme, and its computational complexity is also analyzed.Index Terms-Integrated sensing and communication (ISAC), intelligent reflecting surface (IRS), channel estimation, deeplearning, neural networks.

I. INTRODUCTION

T HE integrated sensing and communication (ISAC) technology has been foreseen as a promising candidate to improve wireless resource utilization and hardware sharing efficiency in the next wireless system generations [1], [2], [3]. ISAC merges the sensing and communication (SAC) functionalities into a single system. The sensing functionality of ISAC collects and extracts the sensory information from noisy observations. Thus, it is envisioned as a critical enabler to measure or predict the surrounding wireless environment intelligently. On the other hand, the communication functionality processes and transfers the received noisy signals, with the ultimate goal of recovering the transmitted information accurately. Based on these concepts, to successfully integrate SAC into a single system and expand ISAC to a wide variety of wireless networks, the performance trade-off between SAC has been analyzed in the literature [4], [5], [6], [7], [8]. The authors in [4] and [5] focused on optimizing the sensing functionality, such as the target detection probability and target angle estimation accuracy, while guaranteeing an acceptable communication performance. On the other hand, the sensing-assisted communication scheme that promotes the communication performance was investigated in [6], [7], [8], including the sensing-assisted beam training, tracking, and prediction. The aforementioned works typically assumed that perfect channel state information (CSI) is available at the receiver side and rarely considered the channel estimation issue for the ISAC systems. Recently, another interesting study of sensing-assisted communication was performed in [9], which designed the precoder of the roadside units (RSU) and the received beamforming of the vehicle. With the help of the radar mounted on the RSU, the covariance matrices of both SAC channels were estimated by the echo signals to facilitate the transceiver beamforming design. However, the SAC channels in [9] were assumed to share the same dominant paths. Hence, its estimation approach is only limited to that specific case.

Intelligent reflecting surface (IRS) has emerged as another promising technique to increase the coverage and capacity of next wireless system generations; it enables a programmable wireless propagation environment [10], [11], [12], [13]. In general, IRS is an artificial planar surface comprising a large number of low-cost passive reflecting elements. Each element independently configures its phase-shift according to the CSI of the surrounding environment and further controls the reflection of the incident signals [10]. By properly coordinating the phaseshifts of all the IRS elements, the signal transmission quality and system performance can be improved. This technology is referred to as passive beamforming [14], [15], [16]. Note that the above beamforming gain is based on an accurate CSI of the IRS-assisted wireless communication system. As such, estimating the channels is crucial in such a system. Since the reflected channel matrix (e.g., user equipment (UE)-IRS-base station (BS) link) has a large dimension and does not follow the traditional Rayleigh distribution, two challenges come up to the channel estimation [17], [18]. One challenge is the limited estimation accuracy, while the other one is the large training overhead. To overcome these challenges, model-driven channel estimation approaches have been widely researched recently, such as the reflection pattern controlled [19], [20] and element grouping schemes [21], [22]. Despite the vital contributions of these works, the above challenges have not been sufficiently addressed yet. Therefore, the data-driven deep-learning (DL) estimation approaches are further investigated in [23], [24], [25], [26]. These DL-based approaches reflect the potential to balance the estimation accuracy and training overhead in the IRS-assisted communication systems. The mapping between the received signals and channels is successfully characterized by adopting various DL networks, such as convolutional neural network (CNN) [23], [24], recurrent neural network [25], and deep residual learning [26].

Since IRS has shown great prospects in enriching communication coverage and spectral/energy efficiency, it is expected to assist the ISAC system in providing better SAC performance. Recently, ISAC and IRS have been jointly explored, taking into account their cooperation merits [27], [28], [29], [30]. Due to the fact that the SAC signals coexist in the IRS-assisted ISAC systems, inherent interference occurs and affects the SAC performance. Then, the ISAC BS and IRS beamforming, as well as the ISAC waveform, are required to be properly designed for such systems. The authors in [27] and [28] concentrated on the beamforming designs for both the ISAC BS and IRS to provide a tradeoff between SAC performance, considering the effect of inherent interference. On the other hand, the joint ISAC waveform and IRS beamforming designs were investigated for the IRS-assisted ISAC systems in [29] and [30], aiming to mitigate the inherent interference while improving the communication performance under the constraints of sensing metrics. It is worth noting that an accurate CSI is necessary for all the aforementioned designs. The channel estimation problem in such IRS-assisted ISAC systems is challenging due to the inherent interference; to the best of the authors' knowledge, this problem has not been investigated yet. Considering the research gap in the existing literature, this paper proposes a novel three-stage channel estimation approach for an IRS-assisted ISAC multiple-input single-output (MISO) system. Each stage is devised at the full-duplex (FD) ISAC BS, and then a DL estimation framework is developed correspondingly, along with input-output pairs designs. In particular, the contributions of this paper are summarized as follows:

1) A three-stage estimation approach is proposed to estimate the SAC channels of the IRS-assisted ISAC system. It decouples the overall estimation problem into sub-ones by controlling an on/off state of the IRS or BS transmission. The proposed estimator successively estimates the direct SAC, reflected UE-IRS-BS, and reflected BS-target-IRS-BS channels. The proposed approach is the first attempt to provide a practical channel estimation for such a system and successfully solves the estimation difficulty caused by the inherent interference. 2) The pilot transmission protocol for each stage is precisely designed to facilitate the SAC channels estimation. It involves the design of the pilot sequences adopted at the FD ISAC BS, pilot sequences employed at the UE, and IRS phase-shift vectors.


3) A CNN-based DL framework is developed at the ISAC BS

to estimate the SAC channels in three stages. Considering the different propagation environments of the direct and reflected channels, two CNN architectures are carefully designed to form the proposed DL framework. The first CNN is devised for the direct SAC channels estimation in the first stage, while the other one is employed in the second and third stages to estimate the reflected channels. 4) Two types of input-output pairs are proposed for the CNNs. The first type of input-output pair is built on the original received SAC signals, while the second one relies on the least-squares (LS) estimates of the SAC channels. Inspired by the data augmentation in data analysis, the training dataset is further enriched to enhance the estimation accuracy. 5) The computational complexity of the proposed approach for the input generation and CNN-based online estimation is analyzed. Their mathematical formulations are deduced in terms of the required number of real additions and multiplications. Quantitative simulations indicate that the complexity of the proposed approach is acceptable compared to the LS baseline estimator. 6) Extensive simulations are performed to assess the estimation performance of the proposed approach. Numerical results reveal that the proposed approach achieves considerable enhancement in the estimation accuracy compared to the LS baseline scheme under various signal-to-noise ratio (SNR) conditions and system parameters. It also possesses promising generalization capacity under a wide range of SNR regions. The remainder of this paper is organized as follows: Sections II and III introduce the system model and proposed three-stage channel estimation approach for the IRS-assisted ISAC MISO system, respectively. The complexity analysis and simulation results are presented in Sections IV and V, respectively. Finally, the conclusions are drawn in Section VI.

Notations: Boldface lowercase and uppercase letters represent vectors and matrices, respectively. CN (μ, σ 2 ) is the probability density function of a random variable following the complex Gaussian distribution with mean μ and variance σ 2 . For any vector x, diag{x} returns a diagonal square matrix whose diagonal consists of the elements of x. The operators (·) H , (·) T , (·) * , (·) −1 , (·) † , · , vec[·], {·}, {·}, E{·}, and · F stand for the Hermitian, transpose, conjugate, inverse, pseudoinverse, floor, vectorization, real part, imaginary part, expectation, and Frobenius norm of their arguments, respectively. j = √ −1 denotes the imaginary unit. N b a = {a, a + 1, . . . , b} denotes the index set from integer a to b, and a < b.


II. SYSTEM MODEL

Consider an IRS-assisted ISAC MISO system with an FD ISAC BS, a target, an uplink (UL) UE, and IRS, as illustrated in Fig. 1. The ISAC BS is equipped with M transmit antennas and one receive antenna to simultaneously sense the target and  communicate with the UL UE that has M transmit antennas. IRS composed of L passive reflecting elements is employed to assist the SAC. Note that the IRS location impacts system performance (e.g., achievable rate). Here, the IRS is chosen to be near the ISAC BS to ensure the maximum benefit of the system performance [13]. For target sensing, the FD ISAC BS receives the echo signals from the direct BS-target-BS and reflected BS-target-IRS-BS channels. Let b ∈ C M ×1 , A ∈ C M ×L , and g ∈ C 1×L denote the sensing channel coefficients of the BStarget-BS, BS-target-IRS, and IRS-BS links, respectively. The UL communication signals are received at the ISAC BS through the direct UE-BS and reflected UE-IRS-BS channels. Define f ∈ C 1×M and H ∈ C L×M as the communication channel coefficients of the UE-BS and UE-IRS links, respectively. The self-interference (SI) is introduced to the ISAC BS from the SI channel, h ∈ C M ×1 , due to the FD mode.

A pilot transmission protocol is designed and illustrated in Fig. 2 to estimate the SAC channels of the IRS-assisted ISAC MISO system. Regarding the proposed three-stage approach, define S as the -th estimation stage, ∈ N 3 1 . As shown in Fig. 2, in S , the ISAC BS and UL UE respectively send pilot sequences in C S − C S −1 sub-frames with the c-th, c ∈ N C S C S −1 +1 , sub-frame consisting of P S time slots. Note that the duration of the -th estimation stage is from the (C S −1 + 1)-th to the C S -th sub-frame with C S 0 = 1. At the p-th, p ∈ N P S 1 , time slot in each subframe, the pilot signal vectors adopted at the ISAC BS and UL UE are defined as x S p ∈ C M ×1 and z S p ∈ C M ×1 , respectively. Their corresponding pilot signal matrices in one sub-frame are written as X S = [x S 1 , x S 2 , . . . , x S P S ] ∈ C M ×P S and Z S = [z S 1 , z S 2 , . . . , z S P S ] ∈ C M ×P S , respectively. Moreover, denote the IRS phase-shift vector in the c-th sub-frame by v S c ∈ C 1×L . Here, v S c remains constant within one sub-frame. Thus, the received signal at the p-th time slot in the c-th sub-frame, y S c,p , at the ISAC BS can be expressed as
y S c,p = (b H + g diag{v S c }A H )x S p Sensing signal + h H x S p Residual SI + (f + g diag{v S c }H)z S p UL communication signal +n S c,p ,(1)
where v S c = [β c e jϕ c,1 , β c e jϕ c,2 , . . . , β c e jϕ c,L ], in which β c ∈ [0, 1] and ϕ c,l ∈ [0, 2π) with l ∈ N L 1 are the amplitude and phase-shift of the l-th IRS element, respectively. The additive white Gaussian noise n S c,p follows CN (0, σ 2 ) with zero-mean and variance σ 2 . It is worth mentioning that the propagation environment between the transmit and receive antennas of the ISAC BS tends to be slow-varying [31], [32], [33], [34]. As such, the SI channel, h, can be pre-estimated by an LS estimator at the ISAC BS, and the residual SI term in (1) is compensated before estimating the remaining channels [31]. As seen from (1), it is apparent that g diag{v S c } = v S c diag{g}. The equivalent reflected channels of the BS-target-IRS-BS and UE-IRS-BS links are given by
G t = A diag{g H } ∈ C M ×L and G u = diag{g} H ∈ C L×M , respectively. Therefore, y S c,p in (1) can be reformulated as y S c,p = (b H + v S c G t H )x S p
Sensing signal
+ (f + v S c G u )z S p UL communication signal +n S c,p . (2)
Note that the received SAC signals interfere with each other and are hard to be decoupled at the ISAC BS. Hence, the channels in (2) are challenging to be estimated. In the following, the aim is to estimate the SAC channels (i.e., b, G t , f , and G u ) for the IRSassisted ISAC system based on the designed pilot transmission protocol, as shown in Fig. 2.


III. PROPOSED THREE-STAGE ESTIMATION APPROACH

In this section, a DL-based three-stage channel estimation approach is proposed. Firstly, each of the estimation stages is explained in detail. Then, the input-output pairs for the DL networks are designed for the three stages. In light of these, a CNN-based DL estimation framework is further developed.


A. Design of Three-Stage Approach

To simplify the estimation problem in (2), a three-stage channel estimation approach is proposed here. In S 1 , the direct SAC channels (i.e., b and f }) are estimated when all the IRS elements are turned off by the BS backhaul link [17]. By turning on the IRS and controlling the on/off state of the BS transmission in S 2 and S 3 , the reflected channels of the UE-IRS-BS and BS-target-IRS-BS links (i.e., G u and G t ) are successively estimated. The details of each stage are introduced as follows.

1) First Stage: From the first to the C S 1 -th sub-frames, all the IRS elements are turned off to estimate the direct SAC channels (i.e., b and f ). Based on the proposed pilot transmission protocol in Fig. 2, the received signal in the c-th sub-frames, y S 1 c ∈ C 1×P S 1 , at the ISAC BS can be expressed as
y S 1 c = b H X S 1 + fZ S 1 + n S 1 c , c ∈ N C S 1 1 ,(3)
where n S c = [n c,1 , n c,2 , . . . , n c,P S ] ∈ C 1×P S is the noise vector in S . Here, = 1 and S = S 1 . To avoid the impact of interference between SAC signals on the estimation accuracy, let X S 1 and Z S 1 be orthogonal. Denote a matrix by R = [35], and design it as a discrete Fourier transform (DFT) matrix. The (q, w)th entry in R is written as
[(X S 1 ) T , (Z S 1 ) T ] T ∈ C 2M ×P S 1 with P S 1 2MR (q,w) = 1 √ M e j 2π P S 1 qw .
Considering the low pilot overhead demand, let P S 1 = 2M . Consequently, the pilot matrix X S 1 is constructed by selecting the first to the M -th rows of R, whereas Z S 1 is generated by the rest of R (i.e., from the (M + 1)-th to the 2M -th rows).

2) Second Stage: To estimate the reflected communication channel G u in S 2 , the transmission of ISAC BS is turned off, while all the IRS elements are turned on during the (C S 1 + 1)th to the C S 2 -th sub-frames. The received UL communication signal in the c-th sub-frame, y S 2 c ∈ C 1×P S 2 , at the ISAC BS is given by
y S 2 c = f + v S 2 c G u Z S 2 + n S 2 c , c ∈ N C S 2 C S 1 +1 .(4)
The pilot signal matrix, Z S 2 , adopted in S 2 is designed as an
M × P S 2 DFT matrix with P S 2 ≥ M , and its (q, w)-th entry is formulated as Z S 2 (q,w) = 1 √ M e j 2π P S 2
qw . Taking into account the demand for low-pilot overhead, let P S 2 = M . The IRS phaseshift matrix from the (C S 1 + 1)-th to the C S 2 -th sub-frames is denoted by [26], V S 2 is devised as a DFT matrix with C S 2 − C S 1 ≥ L. This is an optimal scheme to enhance the received signal power at ISAC BS and guarantee accurate channel estimation [26].

3) Third Stage: To estimate the reflected sensing channel G t in S 3 , the ISAC BS transmission and IRS are simultaneously turned on. Within the (C S 2 + 1)-th to the C S 3 -th sub-frames, the ISAC BS receives both SAC signals from the direct and reflected channels. The received signal in the c-th sub-frame,
y S 3 c ∈ C 1×P S 3 , at the ISAC BS is y S 3 c = b H + v S 3 c G t H X S 3 + f + v S 3 c G u Z S 3 + n S 3 c , c ∈ N C S 3 C S 2 +1 . (5)
In S 3 , the adopted pilot matrices (i.e., X S 3 and Z S 3 ) are devised as the M × P S 3 DFT matrices with P S 3 = M , considering the low-pilot overhead demand. The (q, w)-th entry in them is given by
X S 3 (q,w) = Z S 3 (q,w) = 1 √ M e j 2π P S 3 qw . De- note the IRS phase-shift matrix in S 3 by V S 3 = [(v S 3 C S 2 +1 ) T , (v S 3 C S 2 +2 ) T , . . . , (v S 3 C S 3 ) T ] T ∈ C (C S 3 −C S 2 )×L and design it as a DFT matrix with C S 3 − C S 2 ≥ L [26].

B. Input-Output Pairs Design

Based on the received signals at the ISAC BS, the generation of input-output pairs for the DL networks is designed in the three estimation stages.

1) First Stage: To estimate the direct SAC channels (i.e., b and f ), two types of input-output pairs for the DL are devised in S 1 . Let I k denote the k-th input-output pair type, k ∈ N 2 1 . Then, the first input of the DL, T S 1 I 1 , is directly generated by the received SAC signals in (3) as
T S 1 I 1 = y S 1 1 , . . . , y S 1 C S 1 , y S 1 1 , . . . , y S 1 C S 1 T .(6)
The second input of the DL, T S 1 I 2 , is constructed by utilizing the LS estimation results of the direct SAC channels that are respectively denoted byb ∈ C M ×1 andf ∈ C 1×M . Since the pilot matrices (i.e., X S 1 and Z S 1 ) are orthogonal, the estimated b andf are respectively given bȳ

3) Third Stage: Similar to the previous stages, two types of input-output pairs for the DL are designed to estimate the reflected sensing channel G t in S 3 . Based on the estimated channels (i.e.,b,f , andĜ u ) from the previous stages and the received signals in (5), the first input of the DL, T S 3 I 1 , is designed as

C. Proposed CNN-Based DL Framework

On the basis of the proposed three-stage estimation approach and the designed input-output pairs, a CNN-based DL framework is proposed. It comprises the offline training and online estimation phases, as depicted in Fig. 3. The training dataset is generated to train the proposed DL framework.

1) Training Dataset Generation: For the three estimation stages, the training datasets of the DL are generated by the devised input-output pairs. Regarding the k-th type of input-output pair in S , the corresponding training dataset is denoted by 1) , . . . , 2) , . . . ,
(T S I k , O S ) = T S I k (1,1) , O S (1) , T S I k (1,2) , O S(T S I k (1,U ) , O S (1) , T S I k (2,1) , O S(T S I k (V,U) , O S (V ) , ∈ N 3 1 , k ∈ N 2 1 ,(25)
where

1 , training sample. For further understanding, take the training dataset (T S 1 I 1 , O S 1 ) as an example to illustrate its generation process in detail. Inspired by the data augmentation in data analysis, the inputs of the DL in this dataset are constructed by using V received signals in S 1 (i.e., SAC signals formulated in (3)), and U − 1 copies of the v-th, v ∈ N V 1 , are generated by adding synthetic additive white Gaussian noise to the original SAC channels with SNR ch = P ch σ 2 ch . The synthetic noise follows CN (0, σ 2 ch ) with zero-mean and variance σ 2 ch , and the power of the original channel is P ch [23]. Accordingly, the noise corrupted SAC channels can be utilized to obtain the signal copies and further generate the copy samples (i.e., (

is generated. Note that the generation of these copies intends to enrich the training dataset and improve the estimation performance of the proposed DL. Moreover, the training datasets for S 2 and S 3 are constructed similarly as in S 1 .

2) Offline Training: As seen from Fig. 3(a), the offline training phase for each stage contains two procedures, including the data pre-processing and the DL network training. The data pre-processing is performed on the training datasets, consisting of the input standardization and the output scaling with a factor of δ = 10 4 . By utilizing the pre-processed samples, the networks in the proposed framework are trained to obtain well-trained networks. Two different CNN architectures are devised to realize this framework. One CNN is employed in S 1 for the direct SAC channels estimation, referred to as direct estimation CNN (DE-CNN), while the other CNN is adopted in S 2 and S 3 for the reflected SAC channels estimation, namely reflected estimation CNN (RE-CNN).

The detailed offline training phase is illustrated here. Given the training dataset of the k-th type in S (i.e., (T S I k , O S )), the (v, u)-th input-output pair in this dataset is pre-processed as (T S I k (v,u) ,Ō S (v) ). Then, during the training procedure, the de-
signed CNN approximatesŌ S (v) as O S (v) ≈ f S I k T S I k (v,u) ; Θ S I k , v ∈ N V 1 , u ∈ N U 1 ,(26)
where f S I k (· ; Θ S I k ) represents the CNN function that corresponds to the k-th type input-output pair in S , and Θ S I k denotes all CNN hyperparameters. To update Θ S I k , the designed CNN minimizes the mean square error (MSE) of the loss function, L S I k , as Fig. 3(a) shows the architectures of the DE-CNN and RE-CNN, which combine the benefits of the convolutional layer (CL) and the feedforward layer (FFL). As for CL, the neurons are locally connected, and a group of connections among them is assigned the same weight. Thus, by introducing CL into a DL network, the network parameters are effectively decreased, and the convergence is accelerated compared with a fully connected network [36]. The FFL is further combined with the CL to enhance the estimation accuracy and generalize the ability of Considering the aforementioned benefits, the hidden layers in the DE-CNN consist of one CL and one FFL with a flatten layer between them. Since the propagation environment of the reflected SAC channels is more complicated, the hidden layers in the RE-CNN increase to two CLs and two FFLs to promote its feature extraction ability. All the CLs utilize the tanh activation function, while the FFLs adopt the linear one. The Adam optimizer with a learning rate of 2 × 10 −4 is employed to update the CNN parameters. The minibatch transitions of size 200 are randomly selected to reduce the correlation of the training samples. Furthermore, a stopping criterion is adopted in the training process, i.e., the training stops if the validation accuracy does not improve in N s = 5 consecutive epochs or the training epochs reach the maximum number of epochs N e = 200. The remaining hyperparameters of the DE-CNN and RE-CNN are summarized in Table I. 3) Online Estimation: The online estimation phase for the three stages is illustrated in Fig. 3(b), comprised of data preprocessing, channel estimation with the trained DL network, and data post-processing. First, the testing dataset of the k-th type in the -th stage,Ṫ S I k , is pre-processed to derive the standardized samples asT S I k . Then, the output of the trained CNN,Õ S , is obtained byÕ
L S I k = 1 V U v∈N V 1 ,u∈N U 1 f S I k T S I k (v,u) ; Θ S I k −Ō S (v) 2 .(27)S = f S I k (T S I k ;Θ S I k ),(28)
whereΘ S I k denotes the hyperparameters of the trained CNN. Further, by scalingÕ S with a factor of δ −1 and performing straightforward mathematical operations (i.e., combine the real and imaginary parts inÕ S to the complex numbers), the channels of the direct SAC, reflected communication, and reflected sensing channels are successively estimated as {b,f },Ĝ u , andĜ t . The proposed CNN-based SAC channels estimation algorithm is summarized in Algorithm 1, where t S I k represents the index of the training epoch that corresponds to the k-th type of input-output pair in S .

IV. COMPLEXITY ANALYSIS

This section discusses the computational complexity of the proposed approach for inputs generation and CNN-based online estimation. The number of real additions and multiplications are considered to assess the complexity.


A. Complexity of Inputs Generation

Since the generation of the first type of inputs (i.e., T S 1 I 1 , T S 2 I 1 , and T S 3 I 1 ) does not require signal pre-processing, there is no additional computational complexity.

For the generation of the second type of input in S 1 (i.e., T S 1 I 2 ), the computational complexity comes from (7) and (8). Thus, the number of real additions and multiplications, C S 1 I 2 A and C S 1 I 2 M , required to generate the input T S 1 I 2 are given respectively by
C S 1 I 2 A = 10 3 C S 1 M (2M 2 − 1) − 2M,(29)
and
C S 1 I 2 M = 2 3 C S 1 M (52M 2 + 39M − 1) + 4M + 2.(30)
Regarding the generation of the second type of input in S 2 (i.e., T S 2 I 2 ), the complexity is introduced by (12), (13), and (15). The cost of (12) isC S 2 I 2 A = 2M 2 real additions and C S 2 I 2 M = 4M 2 real multiplications in each sub-frame. Particularly, for the inverse calculation of a complex q × q matrix, the required number of real additions and multiplications are C inv,q A = 2 3 q(3q 2 + 3q − 1) and C inv,q M = 1 3 q(4q 2 + 15q − 1), respectively [37]. Then, the cost of (13) 
isC S 2 I 2 A = 2M (2M 2 − M − 1) + C inv,M A real additions andC S 2 I 2 M = 4M 2 (2M + 1) + C inv,M M
real multiplications in each sub-frame. The LS estimator in (15) 
costsC u A = (4L 2 − 2L)(C S 2 − C S 1 ) − 2L 2 + C inv,L A andC u M = 8L 2 (C S 2 − C S 1 ) + C inv,L M
real additions and multiplications, respectively. Therefore, the number of real additions and multiplications, C S 2 I 2 A and C S 2 I 2 M , required to generate the input T S 2 I 2 can be expressed respectively as
C S 2 I 2 A = (C S 2 − C S 1 )(C S 2 I 2 A +C S 2 I 2 A ) +C u A = 2 3 (C S 2 − C S 1 )(9M 3 + 3M 2 − 4M + 6L 2 − 3L) + 2 3 L(3L 2 − 1),(31)
and
C S 2 I 2 M = (C S 2 − C S 1 )(C S 2 I 2 M +C S 2 I 2 M ) +C u M = 1 3 (C S 2 − C S 1 )(22M 3 + 39M 2 − M + 24L 2 ) + 1 3 (4L 2 + 15L + 1).(32)
The second type of input in S 3 (i.e., T S 3 I 2 ) is generated according to (19), (20), and (22). In each sub-frame, the cost of (19) is C S 3 I 2 A = 2M (2M + L) real additions andC S 3 I 2 M = 4M (2M + L) real multiplications. With straightforward derivation, the complexity of (20) and (22) is respectively equal to (13) and (15). Hence, the number of real additions and multiplications, C S 3 I 2 A and C S 3 I 2 M , required to generate T S 3 I 2 are given respectively by
C S 3 I 2 A = 2 3 (C S 3 − C S 2 )(9M 3 + 6M 2 − 4M + 3ML + 6L 2 − 3L) + 2 3 (3L 2 − 1),(33)
and
C S 3 I 2 M = 1 3 (C S 3 − C S 2 )(22M 3 + 51M 2 − M + 12ML + 24L 2 ) + 1 3 L(4L 2 + 15L − 1).(34)

B. Complexity of DE-CNN and RE-CNN

Referring to the proposed CNN-based estimation framework, the computational complexity of the proposed DE-CNN and RE-CNN comes from the computational complexity calculation of each layer. To formulate the general expressions of the computational complexity, consider η i and F n i as the number of neurons and filters in the i-th layer, respectively, while F z denotes the filter size of the CL. Their exact values are presented in Table I.

For computational simplicity, the cost of each activation function is considered as one real addition.

Regarding the proposed DE-CNN, the computational complexity is introduced by the computational complexity calculation of the second, third, and fourth layers. Their required number of real additions is respectively expressed as F n 2 η F 2 (F z + 1), η 3 (F n 2 η F 2 + 1), and η 4 (η 3 + 1), whereas that of the real multiplications is respectively given by F n 2 η F 2 F z , F n 2 η F 2 η 3 , and η 3 η 4 . Here, η F 2 = η 1 −F z F s + 1 represents the output size of one filter in the second CL, and F s = 1 is the stride. Therefore, the required number of real additions and multiplications, C DE A and C DE M , for the DE-CNN are given respectively by
C DE A = F n 2 η F 2 (F z + η 3 + 1) + η 4 (η 3 + 1) + η 3 ,(35)
and
C DE M = F n 2 η F 2 (F z + η 3 ) + η 3 η 4 .(36)
Similarly, the computational complexity of the proposed RE-CNN comes from the computational complexity calculation of the second to the sixth layers. For both the second and third CLs (i.e., i ∈ N 3 2 ), the required number of real additions and multiplications are F n i η F i (F z + 1) and
F n i η F i F z , respectively. Define η F 3 = F n 2 η F 2 −F z F s + 1
as the output size of one filter in the third CL. The cost of the computational complexity calculation for the fourth layer is η 4 (F n 3 η F 3 + 1) real additions and F n 3 η F 3 η 4 real multiplications. For both the fifth and sixth layers (i.e., i ∈ N 6 5 ), the computational complexity calculation costs η i (η i−1 + 1) real additions and η i η i−1 real multiplications. Hence, the required number of real additions and multiplications, C RE A and C RE M , for the RE-CNN can be written respectively as
C RE A = i∈N 3 2 F n i η F i (F z + 1) + i∈N 6 5 η i (η i−1 + 1) + η 4 (F n 3 η F 3 + 1),(37)
and
C RE M = i∈N 3 2 F n i η F i F z + i∈N 6 5 η i η i−1 + F n 3 η F 3 η 4 .(38)

V. SIMULATION RESULTS

This section quantitatively evaluates the performance of the proposed three-stage channel estimation approach for the IRSassisted ISAC system, considering the LS estimator as the baseline scheme. The simulation setup is firstly provided. Then, the channel estimation performance of the proposed approach is unveiled under various SNR conditions and system parameters. Ultimately, the computational complexity of the proposed approach in terms of different system parameters is investigated.


A. Simulation Setup

In simulations, M = 4, L = 30, C S 1 = 1, C S 2 = L + 1, and C S 3 = 2L + 1 unless further specified. As in [2], the sensing channel of the BS-target-IRS link is modeled as where α 1 denotes the complex-valued reflection coefficient of the BS-target-IRS link, and its phase-shift is uniformly distributed from [0, 2π) [2], [38]. For theM array elements, define the steering vector a(θ) associated with the azimuth angleθ as
A = α 1 a(θ BT )a(θ TI ) H ,(39)a(θ) = 1, e j 2πd λ sin(θ) , . . . , e j 2πd λ (M −1) sin(θ) T ,(40)
whered and λ are the inter-element spacing and signal wavelength, respectively. Then, a(θ BT ) and a(θ TI ) in (39) can be obtained according to (40).
Letθ = θ BT ,d = d B , andM = M in a(θ BT ), whileθ = θ TI ,d = d I , andM = L in a(θ TI ).
Here, θ BT and θ TI represent the azimuth angles of the target and IRS, respectively associated with the BS-target and target-IRS links. Without loss of generality, the antenna spacing of the ISAC BS and distance between two adjacent IRS elements, d B and d I , satisfy d B = d I = ρ 2 . Similar to (39), the BS-target-BS channel is modeled as b = α 2 a(θ BT ) with α 2 as its reflection coefficient, which follows the same distribution as α 1 with |α 1 | = |α 2 | = 1. The rest of the channels are modeled as Rician fading [26]. As such, the channel of the IRS-BS link is given by
g = K IB K IB + 1 g LoS + 1 K IB + 1 g NLoS ,(41)
where K IB = 10 is the Rician factor of the IRS-BS channel.

Here, g LoS and g NLoS respectively denote the line-of-sight (LoS) component and non-LoS (NLoS) component of g. By utilizing (40), define g LoS = a(θ IB ) H , where θ IB is the azimuth angle from the IRS to the BS. The communication channels (i.e., f and H) can be modeled similarly as in (41), and their Rician factors are set to 0 (i.e., Rayleigh fading). Furthermore, a distance-dependent path loss model is adopted to characterize the path loss factor of each channel. As shown in Fig. 4, the path loss at distance d j , j ∈ N 5 1 , is modeled as ρ j = ρ 0 ( d j d 0 ) −γ j , where ρ 0 = −30 dBm is the path loss at the reference distance d 0 = 1 m, and γ j denotes the path loss exponent [13], [39]. The distances are set to d 1 = 2 m, d 2 = d 3 = 140 m, and d 4 = d 5 = 50 m. The azimuth angles are θ BT = arccos( d 1 d 5 ), θ TI = − arccos( d 1 d 5 ), and θ IB = π. The corresponding path loss exponents are γ 1 = 2, γ 2 = 3.5, γ 3 = 2.3, γ 4 = 3, and γ 5 = 2.2 [13]. Referring to [39], the transmit power of the ISAC BS and UL UE is set to P B = 20 dBm and P U = 15 dBm, respectively.

The hyperparameters of the proposed DE-CNN and RE-CNN are summarized in Table I. For the offline training phase, the training dataset size is set to T off = V U = 10 4 for each SNR condition with V = 10 3 , U = 10, and SNR ch = 30 dB. Adopt 90% of the dataset for training and the remaining dataset for testing. As seen from Fig. 5, the convergence properties of the proposed CNNs (i.e., DE-CNN for S 1 and RE-CNN for S 2 and S 3 ) are evaluated by using the data samples generated at SNR = 15 dB. It is shown that the DE-CNN and RE-CNN trained by the different types of input-output pairs provide fast convergence, while the MSE in terms of training and testing are extremely close. For the online estimation phase, different T on = 10 3 data samples are tested to verify the estimation performance for various SNR conditions. The SNR used in the simulations is defined as SNR = P r σ 2 , where P r and σ 2 respectively represent the received signal power and noise power at the ISAC BS. For the three stages (i.e., S 1 , S 2 , and S 3 ), P r equals P B ρ 2 + P U ρ 4 , P U (ρ 4 + ρ 1 ρ 5 ), and P B (ρ 2 + ρ 1 ρ 3 ) + P U (ρ 4 + ρ 1 ρ 5 ), respectively. To assess the estimation performance, the normalized MSE (NMSE) is utilized as a performance metric, and is given by
NMSE = E Estimated − True 2 F True 2 F .(42)
B. NMSE Versus SNR Fig. 6 illustrates the impact of SNR on the NMSE performance for the proposed DL approach and LS baseline scheme. Consider SNR = [10,20] dB with a step size of 5 dB in the offline training phase, while SNR = [−10, 20] dB with a step size of 2.5 dB for online estimation.

The NMSE performance of the direct SAC channels estimation is depicted in Fig. 6(a). As can be observed, for both b and f , the proposed DL approach provides a comparable estimation performance to the LS baseline scheme when trained by the different types of input-output pairs (i.e., (T S 1 I 1 , O S 1 ) and (T S 1 I 2 , O S 1 )), while it is superior to the LS baseline scheme. One can also note that compared to the LS baseline scheme, the proposed DL approach attains 12.5 dB SNR improvement at NMSE = 10 −1 for estimating b. The performance improvement is more noticeable than that for estimating f . The reason is that the sensing channel model of b is simpler than the communication one for f , and thus, the mapping of the input-output pairs for b is easier to be learned by the proposed DE-CNN.

Based on the estimatedf at S 1 , Fig. 6(b) shows the estimation performance of the reflected communication channel, G u . It is shown that the NMSE performance of the proposed DL approach is comparable to the LS baseline scheme when trained by the different types of input-output pairs (i.e., (T S 2 I 1 , O S 2 ) and (T S 2 I 2 , O S 2 )), whereas it significantly outperforms the LS baseline scheme, especially in the low SNR region. For instance, the proposed DL approach achieves around 4 dB SNR improvement at NMSE = 10 −1 compared to the LS baseline scheme. Fig. 6(c) evaluates the estimation performance of the reflected sensing channel G t , based on the estimated {b,f } andĜ u from the previous stages. By adopting the second type of input-output pair (T S 3 I 2 , O S 3 ), the proposed DL approach achieves up to 12.5 dB SNR improvement at NMSE = 10 −1 compared to the LS baseline scheme. Moreover, 7 dB SNR improvement is obtained by the proposed DL approach when using the first type of input-output pair (T S 3 I 1 , O S 3 ). This lies in that the proposed RE-CNN can correct partial estimation errors introduced by S 1 and S 2 if trained by (T S 3 I 1 , O S 3 ). Note that the generation of T S 3 I 1 builds on the original received signals without a need of signal pre-processing (i.e., y S 3 c ), as formulated in (18). On the contrary, when trained by (T S 3 I 2 , O S 3 ), the RE-CNN cannot correct the previous estimation errors since T S 3 I 2 in (23) relies on the LS estimation results (i.e.,Ḡ t in (22)). These rough estimations have been corrupted by the previous estimation errors during signal pre-processing, thus, affecting the estimation accuracy. By taking a deep look at Fig. 6(b) and (c), one can note that compared to the LS baseline scheme, the performance improvement of the proposed DL approach is more noticeable for estimating G t than that for estimating G u . This is due to the fact that the sensing channel model of G t is simpler than the communication one of G u . The mapping of the input-output pairs of G t is more straightforward to be trained by the proposed RE-CNN, and the estimation accuracy of G t is further enhanced. In addition to the outstanding NMSE performance, Fig. 6 also unveils that the proposed DL approach exhibits an excellent generalization capacity since the CNNs are trained for several specific SNR conditions that can be extended to a wide range of SNR regions.


C. NMSE Versus Channel Dimension

Note that L directly affects the channel dimension of G u and G t . Therefore, Fig. 7 illustrates the impact of increasing L on the estimation performance. The SNR in the offline training and online estimation phases is fixed to 0 dB and 10 dB, respectively. Fig. 7(a) depicts the NMSE performance of the reflected communication channel G u . It is obvious that the proposed DL estimation approach attains significant performance enhancement compared to the LS baseline scheme for different L values and SNR conditions. The proposed DL approach trained by the second type of input-output pair is robust to the change of L, whereas that trained by the first one slightly increases as L increases. This lies in the fact that the generation of the first input T S 2 I 1 does not require a signal pre-processing, and thus, the mapping of (T S 2 I 1 , O S 2 ) is more challenging to be learned accurately by the RE-CNN when the channel dimension becomes larger. Fig. 7(b) illustrates the estimation performance of the reflected sensing channel G t . Apparently, the proposed DL approach outperforms the LS baseline scheme under different L and SNR setups, and is robust to the change of L. One can also note that the proposed DL approach using the first type of input-output pair provides a better estimation accuracy than that with the second one at SNR = 0 dB, while the opposite occurs for SNR = 10 dB. The former is attributed to the error correction ability of the proposed RE-CNN when trained by (T S 3 I 1 , O S 3 ), same as the findings in Fig. 6(c). The latter lies in that the estimation errors from the previous stages are minor in the high SNR region and the mapping of (T S 3 I 2 , O S 3 ) is easy to be learned by the proposed RE-CNN, thus, enhancing its NMSE performance.

To sum up, the above essential observations in Fig. 7 unveil that the first type of input-output pairs (i.e., (T S 2 I 1 , O S 2 ) and (T S 3 I 1 , O S 3 )) are preferable in the estimation cases of harsh SNR conditions and small channel dimensions, whereas the second ones (i.e., (T S 2 I 2 , O S 2 ) and (T S 3 I 2 , O S 3 )) are recommended for the opposite scenarios. Fig. 8 studies the impact of varying M on the estimation performance. The SNR conditions are the same as in Fig. 7 with L = 15. The NMSE performance of the direct SAC channels (i.e., b and f ) is investigated in Fig. 8(a). As can be observed, the proposed DL approach performance is superior to the LS baseline scheme for estimating b, while its performance is comparable with the LS baseline scheme for estimating f . Moreover, by adopting the proposed DL approach, the NMSE performance of estimating b decreases as M increases. This lies in the fact that the proposed DE-CNN can extract more distinguishable features of b to improve the estimation accuracy when M becomes larger. Fig. 8(b) and (c) respectively assess the estimation performance of the reflected SAC channels (i.e., G u and G t ). Obviously, for the estimation of G u and G t , the proposed DL approach outperforms the LS baseline scheme under different M values and SNR conditions. Other findings from these two figures are similar as in Fig. 7(a) and (b). Particularly, the NMSE of estimating G u achieved by the proposed DL approach is more robust to the change of M when the RE-CNN is trained by the second type of input-output pair, as seen in Fig. 8(b). For the estimation of G t in Fig. 8(c), the proposed DL approach trained by the first type of input-output pair (i.e., (T S 3 I 1 , O S 3 )) is superior to that with the second one (i.e., (T S 3 I 2 , O S 3 )) at SNR = 0 dB, and vice versa at SNR = 10 dB.

By taking an in-depth look at Figs. 8(c) and 7(b), one can also note that when the proposed DL approach adopts (T S 3 I 2 , O S 3 ), the NMSE of estimating G t slightly decreases as M increases in Fig. 8(c), whereas it is stable for different L values in Fig. 7(b). This interesting finding is attributed to two aspects, as follows. First, the increase of L affects both BS-target-IRS and IRS-BS links (i.e., A and g) of G t = A diag{g H }, while the increase of M only impacts A. This makes the channel estimation simpler when increasing M rather than L. Second, since the mapping of (T S 3 I 2 , O S 3 ) is easier than (T S 3 I 1 , O S 3 ), the proposed RE-CNN trained by (T S 3 I 2 , O S 3 ) attains a superior feature extraction ability and enhances the estimation accuracy of G u when M becomes larger.


D. Complexity Assessment

The complexity of the proposed DL approach and LS baseline scheme is assessed in this subsection, considering the impact of increasing L and M . Based on the deduced formulations in Section IV, the complexity of the proposed DL approach is measured by adding up the cost of the inputs generation and CNN-based online estimation. The required number of real additions and multiplications, C A and C M , is respectively shown in the solid and dashed curves in Fig. 9.

As depicted in Fig. 9, for the estimation of {b, f } and G u , the complexity of the proposed DL approach trained by the first and second types of input-output pairs is comparable to the LS baseline estimator. For estimating G t , the proposed DL approach using (T S 3 I 2 , O S 3 ) attains lower complexity than that with (T S 3 I 1 , O S 3 ). One can also observe from Fig. 9 that the complexity of the proposed DL approach increases as L or M increases, and is higher than that of the LS baseline scheme. It can be inferred from Figs. 6-9 that the proposed DL approach provides outstanding NMSE performance at the expense of an acceptable computational complexity compared to the LS baseline scheme. 


VI. CONCLUSION

This paper has proposed a DL-based three-stage channel estimation approach, for the first time, for the IRS-assisted ISAC MISO system. The proposed DL framework realized by the DE-CNN and RE-CNN has been developed to successively estimate the direct SAC channels, reflected communication channel, and reflected sensing channel. The pilot transmission protocol for the ISAC BS, UL UE, and IRS has been devised to facilitate the SAC channels estimation in each stage. Two types of input-output pairs have been designed for the CNNs. Numerical results have indicated that under different SNR conditions, the proposed DL approach provides a considerable generalization capacity and significantly enhanced NMSE performance (e.g., 12.5 dB SNR improvement at NMSE = 10 −1 for sensing channel estimation), compared to the LS baseline scheme. Furthermore, under a wide range of channel dimensions, the proposed DL approach possesses a remarkable NMSE performance improvement over the LS baseline scheme. The superiority of the proposed DL approach is attributed to the unique advantages of the designed input-output pairs, as well as the feature extraction and error correction abilities of the proposed CNN architectures. The computational complexity of the proposed DL approach has been investigated, and results showed an acceptable complexity to achieve an accurate channel estimation.
